p: Severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS‐CoV‐2) has killed more than 14 million people [1]. The global pandemic and social disruption prompted the accelerated clinical application of COVID‐19 vaccines worldwide [2]. Since December 8, 2020, emergency use authorisation of mRNA vaccines (such as BNT162b2 (Pfizer‐BioNTech) and mRNA‐1273 (Moderna)) has been granted, and vaccination became compulsory in many countries. COVID‐19 mRNA vaccines are highly effective in preventing severe COVID‐19 and have contributed to pandemic control. However, the vaccines were rapidly approved, and unlike other investigational drugs, limited safety data had been accumulated. According to clinical trial data, most vaccine‐associated adverse events are mild [2]; however, severe adverse reactions such as anaphylaxis, myocarditis, and thrombotic events have also been reported [3]. These events can be fatal, and their mechanisms remain poorly understood. Pneumonitis following COVID‐19 vaccination is rare.
